answers.text: the management of a vertically integrated oil company

qas.question: The development of what two types of exptertise established the core competencies on which the company was founded?
One of the most important business in which Shell is involved is what?
Each business now seeks to become what type of unit?
The business model that provided significant economies of scale and barriers to entry is called what?
What is the least important business for Shell?

plausible_answers.text: significant economies of scale and barriers to entry

qas.question: What did self-supporting units provide for the company?
What types of expertise have been removed from the business?
Which stage does not require technical and commercial expertise?
What company is moving away from having self-supported units?

context: <b9_0>Shell<b9_0/>'s primary business is <a0_0>the management of a vertically integrated oil company<a0_0/>. The development of <a1_0><b7_0>technical and commercial<b7_0/><a1_0/> expertise in <b8_0>all stages<b8_0/> of this vertical integration, from the initial search for oil (exploration) through its harvesting (production), transportation, refining and finally trading and marketing established the core competencies on which the company was founded. Similar competencies were required for <a2_0><b5_0>natural gas<b5_0/><a2_0/>, which has become one of the most important businesses in which Shell is involved, and which contributes a significant proportion of the company's profits. While the <a4_0>vertically integrated<a4_0/> business model provided <b6_0>significant economies of scale and barriers to entry<b6_0/>, each business now seeks to be a <a3_0>self-supporting<a3_0/> unit without subsidies from other parts of the company.
